Problem:
Consider the Laplace Transform of a time-dependent variable \\( x(t) \\) denoted as \\( X(s) = \\mathcal{L}\\{x(t)\\} \\). Now assume the introduction of a function \\( f(t) = e^{at} \\), which alters \\( x(t) \\) to \\( z(t) = x(t)f(t) \\), where \\( a \\) is a constant.

Can we recover the exact form of \\( x(t) \\) from \\( Z(s) \\) at any time t, without knowing a priori that the function \\( f(t) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Not knowing that \\( f(t) \\) was applied obscures the true nature of the original signal \\( x(t) \\). Without this knowledge, it’s impossible to determine whether the shift in the Laplace domain is intrinsic to \\( x(t) \\) or a result of the multiplication by \\( e^{at} \\), thereby precluding precise recovery of \\( x(t) \\).
